p: Influenza pandemics are caused by novel viruses for which the world population has no immunity [ 54, 72]. Each of the six pandemics in the last 120 years were caused by a different novel influenza A virus that has undergone antigenic shift, reassortment of gene segments encoding HA and/or NA, and successfully adapted to the human host [ 53]. However, of the multiple possible combinations between 17 HA genes and 10 NA genes, influenza viruses with only three combinations (H1N1, H2N2, and H3N2) have adapted to enable human-to-human transmission suggesting the presence of inherent limitations in viral ability to adapt [ 72, 73].
